quoteFirst: _Saturday, December 23._ I had to grind up my own colors this morning; I detest it, it makes me hot, fretful, moody, and I am convinced has a bad effect on my mind. However, I worked closely, but the day was shockingly short; I cannot see before
quoteLast: , and am forced to stop at three....
title: Audubon and His Journals, Volume 1
author: Audubon, John James, 1785-1851; Coues, Elliott, 1842-1899 [Annotator]; Audubon, Maria R. (Maria Rebecca), 1843-1925 [Editor]

quoteFirst: At first the club had a room on the ground floor in the Academic Building, but now it has fine quarters on the second floor in the new North Cadet Barracks where, when it does not interfere with duty, members may go at any time between 7:15 a. m. and
quoteLast: and until recall from the hop on cadet hop nights.
title: Cadet Life at West Point
author: Reed, Hugh T., 1850-1934

quoteLast: . I shall take some laudanum to be sure of sleep.

quoteFirst: Halstead, too, leaned forward impressively.  "Willa said nothing about having been out, and naturally such a possibility never occurred to me, but Welsh tells me she drove up in a taxi-cab at
quoteLast: .  She must have slipped out very early, for he did not see her go."

quoteFirst: “Mightn’t have had time to go on with the letter just then,” suggested the inspector. “We know some one was with him at
quoteLast: . If that visitor turned up as soon as you left, and after he went, Miss Ackroyd came in to say good-night—well, he wouldn’t be able to go on with the letter until close upon ten o’clock.”
title: The murder of Roger Ackroyd
author: Christie, Agatha, 1890-1976

quoteFirst: General Coke appears to have left Spion Kop at
quoteLast: for the purpose of consulting with Sir Charles Warren, and up to that hour the idea of a withdrawal had not been entertained. Yet, almost immediately after General Coke's departure Colonel Thorneycroft issued an order, without reference to superior authority, which upset the whole plan of operations, and rendered unavailing the sacrifices which had already been made to carry it into effect.
title: Story of the War in South Africa, 1899-1900
author: Mahan, A. T. (Alfred Thayer), 1840-1914

quoteFirst: Eva Grant stated that the call was made from her apartment about 4 p.m.[C6-1012] Ruby, however, believed it was made from the Turf Bar. He stated that from the Turf Bar he went to the Carousel and then home and has not provided additional details on his activities during the hours from about 4 to
quoteLast: [C6-1013] Robert Larkin saw him downtown at about 6 p.m.[C6-1014] and Andrew Armstrong testified that Ruby visited the Carousel Club between 6 and 7 p.m. and remained about an hour.[C6-1015]
title: Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President John F. Kennedy
author: United States. Warren Commission

quoteFirst: The weather continued bad, and towards evening we were startled by a large rock which came crashing down the mountain-side in close proximity to the hut, warning us that what with falling stones and the danger of a break in the Ball Glacier a few hundred yards higher up the valley, the said hut was in anything but a safe position. Day closed in, and, one by one, we dozed off again till at about
quoteLast: we were aroused by a further noise outside, and in our half-sleepy condition imagined we were going to be bombarded by another rock avalanche. Presently, however, the door opened, and in walked three men with ice-axes, Alpine rope, and other climbing paraphernalia.
title: A climber in New Zealand
author: Ross, Malcolm, 1862-1930; Bryce, James Bryce, Viscount, 1838-1922 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: (N.E.; C. V.) _Nash_ (_E._) L.H., a Woodcock at 7 P.M.; four Snipe from 7 to 7.30 P.M.; a small flock of Lapwings at 8 P.M.; all flying round the lantern. Four *Grey Plover killed at 9 P.M.; eleven Starlings killed at
quoteLast: (E.N.E., 2; O. M. R.) _Breaksea_ L.V., Larks and Starlings at lantern from 6 to 12 P.M. (N.E., 4; O. M. R.) _Longships_ L.H., Chaffinches and Goldcrests at lantern at 7 P.M. (E.N.E.

quoteFirst: They went together to No. 163, Place Egalite, where after stopping an instant, they took a turn in the galleries, and then returned to sup.--They went in at
quoteLast: , and were still there at eleven o'clock, when we came away, not being certain if they would come out again.

quoteLast: by the meetin'-house clock,-- Just the hour of the Earthquake shock! --What do you think the parson found, When he got up and stared around? The poor old chaise in a heap or mound, As if it had been to the mill and ground! You see, of course, if you're not a dunce, How it went to pieces all at once,-- All at once, and nothing first,--
title: The World's Best Poetry, Volume 09: Of Tragedy: of Humour
author: Carman, Bliss, 1861-1929 [Editor]; Gummere, Francis Barton, 1855-1919 [Contributor]

quoteFirst: The ladies brought down their embroidery or netting.  At eleven a tray with wine and water is brought in and a quantity of bed candlesticks, and everybody retires when they like.  The next morning the guests assembled at
quoteLast: in the great gallery which leads to the chapel to go in together to prayers.  The chapel is really a beautiful little piece of architecture, with a vaulted roof and windows of painted glass.
title: Letters from England, 1846-1849
author: Bancroft, Elizabeth Davis, 1803-1886

quoteFirst: Let who will be there, he never takes the slightest notice of them till he emerges from this sanctuary, when, like the _malade imaginaire_, he accosts whoever may be present with a cheerful aspect. He is long at his ablutions, and takes up an hour and a half in dressing. At
quoteLast: he breakfasts with the Queen, the ladies, and any of his family; he eats a couple of fingers and drinks a dish of coffee. After breakfast he reads the 'Times' and 'Morning Post,' commenting aloud on what he reads in very plain terms, and sometimes they hear 'That's a damned lie,' or some such remark, without knowing to what it applies.
title:
The Greville Memoirs, Part 1 (of 3), Volume 3 (of 3)
A Journal of the Reigns of King George IV and King William IV
author: Greville, Charles, 1794-1865; Reeve, Henry, 1813-1895 [Editor]

quoteFirst: “He has not come yet!” wrathfully exclaimed Mr. Galloway. “All the work of the office on his shoulders and mine, the most busy time of the whole year, and here’s
quoteLast: , and no appearance of him! If I live this day out, I’ll complain to Lady Augusta!”
title: The Channings: A Story
author: Wood, Henry, Mrs., 1814-1887

quoteFirst: The two men sprang to the fire which they at once kicked aside. The duchess came out first; she was obliged to put her feet and hands on the burning hearth; her companions followed her. It has
quoteLast: in the morning, and for sixteen hours they had been shut up in the hiding-place without any food.

author: Dumas, Alexandre, 1802-1870; Waller, E. M. (Emily Mary) [Translator]

quoteFirst: She was a true woman, by which is meant now and always that she preferred to allow a man to digest his dinner before she tried to bring him to a rational opinion. But in this case her hands were tied. The Cords dined at eight—or sometimes a little later, and Ben’s boat left for New York at
quoteLast: , so that it would be utterly impossible to postpone the discussion of her future until after dinner. It had to be done at once.
title: The Beauty and the Bolshevist
author: Miller, Alice Duer, 1874-1942

quoteFirst: It was some ten or twelve days later, and the hour was
quoteLast: , and the scene a private salon in the Schweizerhof at Lucerne. It was early November, or very close upon it, and so a fire blazed on the hearth, and the looped-back curtains at the windows showed only a mirrored reflection of what was within.
title: A Woman's Will
author: Warner, Anne, 1869-1913; Caliga, I. H. (Isaac Henry), 1857-1934 [Illustrator]
